Sentence: Marlowe's first assignment becomes complicated by and intertwined with a second plot, which also has its roots in the initial meeting with Sternwood
The night is rainy and Marlowe sees that Carmen Sternwood has gone inside Geiger's house
Entering Geiger's home, Marlowe sees that Carmen is drugged and naked, sitting on a chair

As the plot unfolds, Marlow begins to figure out that Taylor was in love with Carmen Sternwood, and that it was Taylor who killed Geiger in retaliation for the naughty pictures of Carmen that Geiger had taken

Everything comes to an end when Marlowe returns Carmen Sternwood's gun--the gun Carmen had used to try to persuade Brody to return her (Carmen) pictures to her (Carmen)--to her (Carmen), and Carmen asks Marlow to teach her (Carmen) to shoot
Down in the abandoned Sternwood family oil field, Carmen turns her (Carmen) gun on Marlowe in an attempt to kill him (Marlowe)
He (Marlowe) figures out, in the end, that Carmen killed Regan and that Vivian paid Eddie Mars's man, Canino, to hide the body
Marlowe solves the puzzle, allowing Vivian to go free as long as she (Carmen) gets Carmen the help she (Carmen) needs to alleviate her (Carmen) insanity
